description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: May 18, 2020, The Lithuanian Cabinet of Ministers agreed to reopen nurseries and preschool groups as of 18 may. So will non-formal education of children. Pre-school, pre-primary and non-formal education of children shall be carried out by ensuring the required conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for public health safety, hygiene and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment.

description: May 18, 2020, The Lithuanian Cabinet of Ministers agreed to reopen kindergartens and preschool groups. So will the non-formal education of children. Pre-school, pre-primary and non-formal education of children shall be carried out by ensuring the required conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for public health safety, hygiene, and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment. UPDATE: This overarching policy ends on 17 May 2020, as the restrictions are lifted for the youngest age groups while kept for the older children and adults.

description:
"August 7, 2020, The Government of Lithuania announced that non-formal education for children and adults will be carried out remotely or discontinued (until 8 November). The necessary conditions for public health safety, hygiene, provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment must be ensured: 
disinfection; hand hygiene (washing and/or disinfection); prohibition to work for employees with symptoms or if isolation is prescribed."

description: May 10, 2021, The Lithuanian government announced that Provision of pre-school and pre-primary education. Participation in pre-school and pre-primary education is recommended only for those children whose parents (adoptive parents or guardians) have no possibilities of working from home.It is obligatory to follow at all times the requirements laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for the management of the flow of people, safe physical distance, other key requirements for public health safety, hygiene, and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment. This restriction is till May 31, 2021.

It is allowed to attend indoor activities at the same time and children camps for up to 30 children per group until June 30, 2021.

description: On 14th May 2021, Lithuania announced it will donate 200,000 COVID-19 vaccine shots of AstraZeneca to its eastern European neighbours including 100,000 to Ukraine. The shots will go to so-called EU Eastern Partnership countries, including 15,000 to Georgia and 11,000 to Moldova, the government said.Distribution of the remaining 74,000 doses will be decided later. The Eastern Partnership also includes Belarus, Azerbaijan and Armenia.The vaccines will be distributed by Oct. 1, mostly between July and September, when Lithuania expects to have a surplus.

description:
On 6th August 2021, the Lithuanian Health Ministry announced that people in Lithuania who have been given the first shot of a Covid-19 vaccine may choose a different vaccine for their second dose. The people may currently mix BioNTech-Pfizer's Comirnaty vaccine with AstraZeneca's Vaxzevria. People are also recommended to choose a different vaccine for their second shot if they experience severe side effects after the first dose of Comirnaty or Vaxzevria. An interval of 56 to 84 days is recommended between the two different shots.

Upd: This is a one-time measure.

description: The Lithuanian Government decided that from June 1st, 2020, Citizens of the countries of the European Economic Area, the Swiss Confederation, and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, and persons lawfully residing in these countries, who arrive from these countries will be allowed entry to Lithuania provided that the incidence of COVID-19 (coronavirus infection) in their country has not exceeded 25 cases/100 000 population in the last 14 calendar days. No 14 days’ self-isolation will be required for the returnees from these countries. Nor will the self-isolation be applicable to those whose country of residence is on the list of countries that are not subject to isolation.

description: On 7 April 2020, the Parliament of Lithuania approved a pay rise of 60–100 percent for healthcare workers, including medical residents, working in coronavirus hotspots during the lockdown. Respective amendments to the Law on Prevention and Control of Communicable Diseases in Humans were passed unanimously with 120 votes in favor. The salaries of medical workers working in the hotspots of highly dangerous communicable diseases would increase by 60 to 100 percent. The pay rise would be financed from the national budget, instead of the Compulsory Health Insurance Fund.

description: Announced 8 April 2020 and starting 10 April, it will be mandatory to wear facemasks in public in Lithuania. Up until now, it has been only recommended to do so. Executives of legal entities or other responsible persons will face fines ranging from 1,500 to 6,000 euros.

description: Announced 8 April 2020 and starting 10 April, it will be mandatory to wear facemasks in public in Lithuania. Up until now, it has been only recommended to do so. The Seimas of Lithuania earlier increased fines for people flouting quarantine requirements and they now face fines ranging from 500 to 1,000 euros. Executives of legal entities or other responsible persons will face fines ranging from 1,500 to 6,000 euros. UPDATE: In the light of the epidemiological situation and the declining workload in the health sector, the requirements for wearing masks and self-isolation will change from Monday, 4 April. A decision of the State Commander of National Emergency Operations will waive the mandatory requirement to wear masks indoors, with the exception of health, care and nursing facilities and public transport.

description:
On April 29th, 2020, the Lithuanian Government has taken a decision to further ease the lockdown restrictions following the recommendations of the Ministry of Health. This will allow healthcare providers to resume services. 
The Government has decided to enable healthcare providers to resume their services once they are ready. They will have to ensure the availability of appropriate infection control measures to provide for the protection of their staff and patients. Healthcare providers are required to produce a plan for a phased resumption and provision of inpatient and outpatient healthcare services.

description: From 2020 June 02, patients who are provided with so-called day inpatient services, that is, when a person comes to a medical institution in the morning, where procedures are performed, scheduled assistance is provided, and returns home in the evening, the test for the detection of coronavirus infection (COVID-19) will have to be carried out only in the case if a person experiences symptoms characteristic of this disease. description: On the 3rd of June 2020 policy on rapid serological tests has been adopted. Serological tests will be used for several purposes: a) to check if a person has had COVID-19 b) as a late diagnosis, at least 14 days after the onset of coronavirus-specific symptoms, c) to assess what proportion of the population has become ill. It is envisaged that rapid tests could also be performed in cases where a person experiences clear clinical signs of coronavirus infection, but repeat PCR tests are negative.

description:
From 10th March 2022 anyone arriving in Lithuania will be required to have a negative COVID-19 test result done in the past 72 hours. UPDATE: Following the decision of the Government of the Republic of Lithuania to lift COVID-19 related national emergency as of 1 May 2022, travellers when entering Lithuania will no longer be subject to COVID-19 restrictions from the said date:
The passengers are not required to complete the passenger questionnaire neither to have a negative test for COVID-19, even they have not been vaccinated or recovered from COVID-19 disease, travellers from any country of the world are not subject to any requirements – Covid tests, as well as the questionnaires, are no longer needed; there will be no longer requirement to meet the exemption criteria or obtain a special permit to enter Lithuania.

description: On 21 February 2020, the National Public Health Center of Lithuania recommends that people who are returning to Lithuania from China to avoid contact with other people. The National Public Health Center advises remote work as a way of avoiding contact. If this is not possible individuals are able to claim 14 days of sick day leave. In cases where the individual is living with other people and alternative housing is not available, temporary housing can be requested.

description:
On June 1, 2020, the Lithuania Government announced travellers coming from Ireland, Malta and can enter Lithuania, but will be subject to a 14-day self-isolation period.
Easing the lockdown measures, the Lithuanian government has approved that travellers coming from 24 European countries will not be subject to 14 days of self-isolation upon arrival.
Restrictions have been lifted for citizens and lawful residents of the countries of the European Economic Area, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom, who arrive from one of these countries, provided the incidence of COVID-19 in the country where they lawfully reside was less than 15 cases/100 000 population in the last 14 days.
Travellers coming from Ireland, Malta and can enter Lithuania, but will be subject to a 14-day self-isolation period.

description: Lithuania's Ministry of Health requires travellers from countries where the coronavirus incidence rate is over 25 cases per 100 000 citizens to quarantine for 14 days upon arrival in Lithuania. The Ministry of Health announced that starting July 6, 2020, the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe have been removed from the quarantine requirement list, and nine other countries and territories without the status of a state have been added: Central African Republic , Montenegro, Costa Rica, Luxembourg, Palestine, the Sahara Arab Democratic Republic, Serbia, Turks and Caicos Islands and Ukraine. As of June 6th, 2020, 58 countries in total are therefore listed on the quarantine requirement list. The list applies to Lithuanian citizens and residents, as well as foreign nationals who have permission to enter Lithuania.

description: Lithuania Health Minister Aurelijus Veryga announced that from 17 July 2020 a 14-day isolation is mandatory for foreign arrivals from outside the European Economic Area, the Swiss Confederation and the United Kingdom. There are also some expections, as mentiond on <Two weeks of isolation will be mandatory for foreigners arriving from third countries>, exceptions include for seafarers employed by Lithuanian companies engaged in international commercial transport, and by various means of transport (carriers). Due to the nature of their work, they will be able to leave Lithuania before the end of the quarantine period. In addition to this, throughout the emergency and quarantine periods, carriers have been and will continue to be granted exemptions so as not to restrict the movement of goods.

description: Lithuania's Ministry of Health requires travellers from countries where the coronavirus incidence rate is over 25 cases per 100 000 citizens to quarantine for 14 days upon arrival in Lithuania. "As of July 20, 2020, Lithuanian residents returning from Ukraine will no longer be required to stay in isolation for 14 days. Additionally, "Mauritania, the Virgin Islands, and Guam have also been removed from the list of most affected countries; however, five new countries have been added: Croatia, India, Andorra, Namibia, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines." Isolation is mandatory when arriving from the countries on the list, and the list applies to residents of Lithuania returning to Lithuania, and to the foreigners who have a permit to enter Lithuania." As of July 20, 2020, the list consists of 64 countries.

description: The Ministry of Health of Lithuania announced that from 27 July 2020 Lithuanian citizens and foreign nationals with special permits who return from countries where the incidence rate exceeds 16 per 100,000 population are required to stay in isolation for 14 days. This means that travellers from more countries than previously are subject to the quarantine requirement. In total, 75 countries are on the list of countries from which travellers have to quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Ministry of Health of Lithuania announced territories are deemed to be virus-affected, where coronavirus incidence rate exceeds 16 cases per 100 000 population in the last 14 days. Foreign nationals arriving from the countries with the incidence rate above 16 cases are required to stay in isolation for 14 days, while isolation and testing for the coronavirus infection are mandatory to those arriving from the third countries included in the list of the affected countries. In the list updated on August 3, 2020, 88 countries were listed. The Ministry of Health notes that these requirements are applicable in the case of foreigners from the European Economic Area, Switzerland, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Ministry of Health of Lithuania requires that foreigners from countries with an incidence rate of more than 16 need to be quarantined for 14 days, and foreigners from third countries on the list of affected countries need to undergo isolation and testing for new crown virus infection. Starting from 2020.8.10, in view of the worsening epidemic situation in Turkey, Poland, Netherlands, Iceland, Cyprus, San Marino and other continental countries, these countries have been included in the list of affected countries and Canada, Mauritania, Congo and Madagascar have been removed from the list . A total of 100 countries were included in the updated list.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

People returning or transiting trough Poland from countries that are not affected by the coronavirus, only with essential stops, such as refuelling or hygiene, in Poland. Officers performing extradition, transfer or takeover tasks."

description: As of 2021.1.25, people coming to Lithuania from almost every foreign country will need to get tested for Covid-19 no more than 48 hours before departure or within 24 hours after arrival, as well as self-isolate for two weeks. According to the Health Ministry, the 14-day self-isolation period can also be shortened after a person gets tested for Covid-19 on the tenth day of isolation at his or her own expense.

description: As of 2021.2.8, all passengers coming to Lithuania need to present coronavirus test results and self-quarantine. Under the new rules, announced by the Health Ministry, all states have been included into the list of affected countries. All travellers coming to Lithuania now need to present a coronavirus test taken within the last 48 hours or register for one in Lithuania within a day after arriving as well as self-isolate for 14 days. Self-isolation is required even if the test result is negative. The self-isolation period can be shortened by taking another coronavirus test 10 days after coming to the country

description: As of 24 March 2020, stricter measures are imposed on all grocery stores in Lithuania. All visitors should disinfect their hands at the points of entry, shopping trolleys and shopping bags should be cleaned and disinfected after each use. Plastic panels should be installed between cashiers and clients, other protective equipment to be provided. Distance between staff members is at least 2 meters. Visitors should be encouraged to pay by cards. Ban on shopping in supermarkets for more than 2 individuals at a time comes into effect, family members have to go shopping by one.

description:
On March 31, 2020, the municipality of Palanga, a spa town of Klaipėda County in Lithuania, decided to put restrictions on accommodation services to avoid high concentration of people.

“The main goal is to protect local people by minimising contacts and migration to our town,” Akvilę Kilijonienė, the municipal administration director of Palanga, told BNS.

description:
"On April 15, 2020, Lithuanian government has approved of the first phase of easing the lockdown, allowing operation of non-food stores on condition that they have a separate direct entrance from the outside and are able to regulate the flow of customers and other visitors.

Operation has been allowed for service businesses located in stationary service provision settings (supermarkets), such as cleaning services, key making, repair services, etc. They are not subject to the requirement to have a separate entrance from the outside. An additional restriction has been imposed on service providers: direct contact with the customer must not exceed 20 minutes."

description:
"On April 15, 2020, Lithuanian government has approved of the first phase of easing the lockdown, allowing operation of non-food stores on condition that they have a separate direct entrance from the outside and are able to regulate the flow of customers and other visitors.

Operation has been allowed for service businesses located in stationary service provision settings (supermarkets), such as cleaning services, key making, repair services, etc. They are not subject to the requirement to have a separate entrance from the outside. An additional restriction has been imposed on service providers: direct contact with the customer must not exceed 20 minutes." description:
On April 22, 2020, Lithuanian government has announced the second phase of quarantine easing. The ban has been lifted as of Monday, 27 April, of hairdressers and nail parlours, outdoor cafes, libraries, museums and zoos, subject to certain requirements. There will also be a possibility of high-performance outdoor training of certain disciplines.

For cafes, restaurants and bars: they will be able to serve visitors only outdoors, and, as before, provide takeaway food. 

For hairdressers and nail parlours: they are required to ensure at least 10 sq. m. of space per customer and serve no more than one customer at a time, while following the mandatory hygiene requirements.

For certain cultural, leisure, entertainment and sports facilities: visits shall be restricted to groups of no more than two people, except where it is family members. 

For outdoor leisure activities in golf and outdoor tennis courts, outdoor shooting ranges, karting tracks and water board parks: they will be required to ensure 10 sq. m. of space per person, and a distance of at least 10 m between visitors. UPDATE: From April 27th, 2020, outdoor bars and cafes will be allowed to reopen as part of Lithuania's gradual exit from coronavirus lockdown. However, restrictions still apply.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other Businesses
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Size of store limited (e.g. stores smaller than 800 sq meters)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 28th, 2020, Lithuania’s health ministry has imposed strict physical distancing rules and safety measures. Shops must limit the number of customers at one time, masks will remain mandatory in all public spaces, and cafe and restaurant tables have to be placed at least two metres apart.

He also added that "Plazas, squares, streets – nearby cafes will be allowed to set up outdoor tables free of charge this season and thus conduct their activities during quarantine."

description:
As of May 30, 2020, Lithuania's government allowed spas to reopen. UPDATE: The nationwide quarantine, which was introduced in Lithuania in mid-March, will be lifted on June 17, the government decided on Wednesday. However, some restrictions will remain in place. After June 17, wearing facemasks in public will no longer be mandatory, but still recommended. At the moment, everyone must wear masks in shops, public transport, museums and other indoor public spaces.

Outdoor events will remain restricted to 700 people until the end of June and 1,000 people afterwards. Indoor events are not allowed to have more than 150, and 200 people after July 1.

description: As of June 16, 2020, Lithuanian government lifted the national quarantine, starting from June 17, 2020, public health recommendations continue: safety distance 2 meters, may be less if there is a partition or personal protective equipment is worn; distances in queues - not less than 1 meter; disinfection, disinfection of trolleys / bags at points of sale; hand hygiene (washing or disinfection); a ban on working with symptoms or if isolation is prescribed; it is recommended to wear personal protective equipment for both visitors and employees.  No measures in place recommending workplace closures. UPDATE: The second quarantine was introduced on 7 November 2020 (Resolution No. 1226) and after several extensions currently remains in force. Before introducing the second nationwide quarantine, the government tried to implement a localized response by issuing different recommendations, including localized quarantines, for different municipalities.

description: Starting from December 16, 2020, due to a nationwide lockdown in Lithuania, non-food shops will have to close or move trading online. Veterinary and food shops, pharmacies, optical and orthopedic shops will remain open. Food markets will also be allowed to stay open. Exceptions apply to Christmas tree vendors, who can continue to operate outdoors. Services that involve physical contact for more than 15 minutes are prohibited, including hairdressers and other beauty services. Exceptions apply to psychotherapy, emotional, and other health services, as well as professional legal and financial services that cannot be provided remotely

description: From the 15th of February, 2021, Lithuania allows non-food shops, kiosks and pavilions (except for those in the marketplace) with a sales area not exceeding 300 m2 to resume activities. Sales outlets will have to ensure there is a serving area of 20m2 or more, or serve only one customer at a time. Stores will be required to have a direct outside entrance and control customer flow.     Selling flowers indoors and outdoors can resume from the 15th.     Hairdressers and beauty salons will be able to resume activities from the 15th.     Individual activities outdoors supervised by coaches and instructors will be allowed on a 1-1 basis.

description: In Lithuania, starting from March 27, 2021 the provision of public transport is restricted for the movement of persons between municipalities,  except in cases where: to a municipality of place of residence, to a municipality other than the place of residence due to death of close relative;- for work when the place of work is in another municipality, to or from international passenger routes, airports, seaports, bus stations, to receive health care,  in urgent cases where it is necessary to provide assistance/care for a sick or vulnerable person, to/from municipalities adjacent to major cities, for other urgent/essential matters. Restrictions are in place until 6 April.

description: The Government of Lithuania prohibits outdoor events of more than 100 participants from March 12, 2020, until March 27, 2020. Outdoor events with less than 100 participants can take place but only if the organizers ensure the possibility to take care of hand hygiene and guarantee that there will be no visitors to the event from countries declared as affected areas. Also, when organizing events, the audience should be taken into account - the majority of it should not consist of people in the risk group, i.e. y seniors with chronic diseases.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions

description: April 29, 2020, Lithuania. Various outdoor leisure activities are again allowed as long as they take place in open air and in groups of no more than two or in families, while avoiding gatherings of people, e.g. training of dogs, making photographs in open spaces, riding, orienteering  sports. UPDATE: Lithuania is further easing restrictions on May 18, 2020, allowing indoor bars and restaurants to reopen, as well as kindergartens and gyms under strict operating rules.

description: As of 24 March 2020, stricter measures are imposed on all grocery stores in Lithuania. All visitors should disinfect their hands at the points of entry, shopping trolleys and shopping bags should be cleaned and disinfected after each use. Plastic panels should be installed between cashiers and clients, other protective equipment to be provided. Distance between staff members is at least 2 meters. Visitors should be encouraged to pay by cards. Ban on shopping in supermarkets for more than 2 individuals at a time comes into effect, family members have to go shopping by one.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On 27 March, 2020, Latvia's passenger carriers, transport organizers and passengers adopted security measures to reduce the number of carried passengers.

Passenger carriers have been ordered to limit the number of carried passengers. For example, buses are allowed to carry no more than 50% of passengers the bus has seats for.
Carriers also have to ensure the driver is distanced from passengers and perform regular disinfection of the interior of the vehicle.

description:
"On April 15, 2020, Lithuanian government has approved of the first phase of easing the lockdown, allowing operation of non-food stores on condition that they have a separate direct entrance from the outside and are able to regulate the flow of customers and other visitors.

Operation has been allowed for service businesses located in stationary service provision settings (supermarkets), such as cleaning services, key making, repair services, etc. They are not subject to the requirement to have a separate entrance from the outside. An additional restriction has been imposed on service providers: direct contact with the customer must not exceed 20 minutes."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On April 22, 2020, Lithuanian government has announced the second phase of quarantine easing. The ban has been lifted as of Monday, 27 April, of hairdressers and nail parlours, outdoor cafes, libraries, museums and zoos, subject to certain requirements. There will also be a possibility of high-performance outdoor training of certain disciplines.

For cafes, restaurants and bars: they will be able to serve visitors only outdoors, and, as before, provide takeaway food. 

For hairdressers and nail parlours: they are required to ensure at least 10 sq. m. of space per customer and serve no more than one customer at a time, while following the mandatory hygiene requirements.

For certain cultural, leisure, entertainment and sports facilities: visits shall be restricted to groups of no more than two people, except where it is family members. 

For outdoor leisure activities in golf and outdoor tennis courts, outdoor shooting ranges, karting tracks and water board parks: they will be required to ensure 10 sq. m. of space per person, and a distance of at least 10 m between visitors. UPDATE: From April 27th, 2020, outdoor bars and cafes will be allowed to reopen as part of Lithuania's gradual exit from coronavirus lockdown. However, restrictions still apply.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 28th, 2020, Lithuania’s health ministry has imposed strict physical distancing rules and safety measures. Shops must limit the number of customers at one time, masks will remain mandatory in all public spaces, and cafe and restaurant tables have to be placed at least two metres apart.

He also added that "Plazas, squares, streets – nearby cafes will be allowed to set up outdoor tables free of charge this season and thus conduct their activities during quarantine."

What is not allowed as yet, is visiting people in prisons and residential social service institutions for the elderly and for persons with disabilities. Likewise, it is prohibited to provide day care and short-term social care or social welfare services to the elderly in non-residential social service institutions.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Primary schools will also be able to open their doors as of May 25, 2020 and so will special schools for pupils with special education needs due to congenital or acquired disorders. It will be up to school communities to decide whether their school continues to operate at home or in classrooms. UPDATE: As of May 30, 2022, The Lithuanian government announced that basic and secondary education will be allowed to resume in schools. This is also the day for non-formal education to resume work where the specificity of the programmes prevents remote education.

description: From October 9, 2020, people of Raseiniai District in Lithuania are required to wear mask in public. UPDATE: The qualitative nature of the policy has changed. The Lithuanian government has decided in the beginning of October to introduce a local lockdown in Raseiniai District, Western Lithuania, for two weeks, starting from October 9. The measures applied by the district's local authority until now, i.e. the requirement to wear facemasks, to work and study from home, etc., will now be complemented by a midnight curfew for public catering and entertainment venues and restrictions on the number of people in shops.

description: Starting from December 16, 2020, due to a nationwide lockdown in Lithuania, non-food shops will have to close or move trading online. Veterinary and food shops, pharmacies, optical and orthopedic shops will remain open. Food markets will also be allowed to stay open. Exceptions apply to Christmas tree vendors, who can continue to operate outdoors. Services that involve physical contact for more than 15 minutes are prohibited, including hairdressers and other beauty services. Exceptions apply to psychotherapy, emotional, and other health services, as well as professional legal and financial services that cannot be provided remotely
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
As of May 5, 2021, there are some social distancing requirements in Lithuania. 

It is recommended to wear face masks on public transport during the morning and evening peak hours.

It is recommended to wear face masks in public indoor places that are poorly ventilated, crowded, and it is impossible to maintain a safe distance from other people, also on public transport during the morning and evening peak hours.

Visiting patients in hospitals is only possible while wearing protective equipment that covers the nose and mouth.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting hospitals
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of May 17, 2021, there will be restrictions for travelling by regular public transport in Lithuania: in long-distance and suburban transport, passengers will be required to travel seated at a distance of at least one meter between each other, as opposed to city transport, where they will be allowed to travel both sitting and standing, provided that a distance of at least one meter is maintained between them.    It will be allowed to travel by vehicles other than regular public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) or vehicles to commute to/from work, or to go to/from points of COVID-19 (coronavirus infection) vaccination, or to go on tours for up to 10 vaccinated or recovered persons, in groups of up to 2 persons or one family and/or one household members. When providing passenger transportation through a ride-hailing and taxi passenger car services, the driver of the vehicle will not be counted.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
